Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: At the end of the shift, it's time for the routine sweep-up of your designated work area.
Story: I stared at the half-written code on my phone, my thumb hovering over the screen. My mentor’s message echoed in my mind: “Let’s see your code sample at our next meeting.” Three days. I’d promised myself I’d finish it tonight, but the clang of shovels and the foreman’s shout snapped me back to the construction site. My shift was ending, and the dust from the day’s work hung thick in the air. I glanced at the broom leaning against the wall—routine sweep-up time. If I left my area messy, I’d be letting my crew down, risking someone’s safety, and maybe even a warning from the boss. But if I stayed, I’d lose the only quiet hour I had to code before exhaustion took over. My hands ached from hauling bricks, but my mind buzzed with unfinished logic and the weight of my mentor’s expectations. I felt pulled in two directions, the pressure mounting as I tried to decide which responsibility I owed more to—my future in tech, or my duty to my team right now.
